Graphical abstract Enhancing the selective oxidation of glycerol into 1,3-dihydroxyacetone (DHA) on a photoanode is attractive but challenging due to the complex reaction pathway. At present, the 20 % selectivity of DHA products on a BiVO4 photoanode in neutral condition as well as its photocorrosion prove to be below expectations. In this work, we decorated binary co-catalysts MnOx/FeOOH on BiVO4 (denoted BVO/Mn/Fe) for the selective photoelectrocatalytic glycerol to DHA. The BVO/Mn/Fe photoanode exhibited a DHA selectivity of 52 % at 1.2 VRHE with an evolution rate of 193.3 mmol m-2h−1 in pH = 7.0, and maintained 97.2 % of the initial photocurrent after 12 h stability test. The role of MnOx and FeOOH in the selective oxidation of glycerol was investigated through comprehensive spectroscopic and computational methods. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy showed that the middle hydroxyl group preferentially adsorbs onto MnOx surfaces, density function theory calculations verified the optimized rate-determining step and decreased energy barrier by MnOx. Meanwhile, FeOOH significantly increased the active surface states on BiVO4 and produced more hydroxyl radicals. The synergistic effect of MnOx and FeOOH promoted the middle hydroxyl oxidation of glycerol and conversion efficiency to DHA on BiVO4 under neutral condition. Keywords Photoelectrochemical Glycerol oxidation Dihydroxyacetone Selectivity Bismuth vanadate Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Glycerol is regarded as one of the top twelve platform chemicals obtained via transesterification of vegetable oils in the biodiesel manufacturing industries [1]. As a byproduct of biodiesel, its global annual production exceeds 40 million tons [2]. However, the conventional glycerol commodity is very limited. Hence, catalytic oxidation of glycerol to value-added derivatives have attracted increasing interests over the past decades [3,4]. The glycerol oxidation reaction (GOR) can produce various C3-C1 products (Scheme 1 .). Among them, dihydroxyacetone (DHA), widely used in cosmetics, pharmaceuticals, fine chemicals, food and other industries, is regarded as one of the most valuable products of glycerol oxidation [5]. Therefore, selective oxidation of glycerol into DHA is a promising route to consume surplus product while concurrently reaping increased economic returns. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) oxidation has been proven to be a sustainable approach for selective GORs by solar energy. Compared with electro-catalytic method, the photo-induced holes generated on valence band maximum (VBM) of different photoanodes possess different oxidizing ability [6], thus these holes can modulate the competitive between C–C bonds cleavage of glycerol and hydroxy peroxidation in GOR, improve the selectivity as well as lower the overpotential. In addition, the selective oxidation of glycerol can also be affected by the different adsorption of primary and secondary hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface [2,7] It has been reported that WO3 was favorable for the production of glyceraldehyde due to the strong adsorption of the glycerol primary hydroxyl, the {202} facet-exposed WO3 showed 2.7-fold higher productivity of glyceraldehyde than that of {200} facet-exposed WO3 [8]. TiO2 primarily breaks C–C bonds in glycerol oxidation rather than targeting the secondary hydroxyl group, leading to formic acid as the main product with a selectivity of approximately 50.6 % [9]. Also Fe2O3 exhibited a nearly 40 % selectivity of glycerol oxidation products for formic acid generation [10]. Consequently, achieving selective GOR on a suitable semiconductor to generate more valuable products remains a desirable yet challenging goal. Recent reports highlight the superiority of BiVO4 photoanodes for selective oxidation of glycerol into DHA. Since BiVO4 provides a suitable bandgap of ∼2.5 eV that endows photo-generated holes with sufficient energy to overcome the energy requirement for the formation of the tertiary radical on the middle carbon of glycerol (∼1.5 eV) [7]. DFT calculation revealed that the middle carbon glycerol radical was more easily generated on BiVO4, resulting in high DHA selectivity [11]. However, a survey of the previous studies presented that the selectivity of DHA on BiVO4 was only about 20 % under neutral condition, while acid media (pH = 2) was conducive to the 51 % selectivity of DHA [11,12]. Electrolyte anion and cation significantly affects the obtained products, glycolaldehyde, a C2 species, emerged as the most dominant product in NaNO3 or H3BO3 electrolyte [13,14]. Engineering bismuth-rich domains and oxygen vacancies increased the DHA selectivity from 54.0 % to 80.3 % in pH = 2 [15]. As the GOR selectivity of BiVO4-based photoanodes continues to improve, the photostability becomes an important issue. The anodic photocorrosion is a typical problem for BiVO4. This process involves the loss of V5+ ions from the BiVO4 lattice by dissolution [16], and suffers from photoelectrochemical instability in both near-neutral and alkaline pH ranges [17,18]. Some GOR byproducts, such as glyceric acid, glycolic acid and formic acid, may intensify the photocorrosion. Incorporating a catalyst layer on BiVO4 surface increases the rate of interfacial charge transfer or the surface separation rate, photocorrosion can be kinetically suppressed [16,19]. For instance, adding Fe2+ in the electrolyte made the BiVO4 photoanode retained a stability for over 200 h without an obvious drop [20], since ferric ions were incorporated onto the surface of BiVO4. BiVO4 modified by NiCo-LDH maintained a performance for 70 h [21], but the DHA selectivity only reached about 20 % at 1.4 V vs. RHE. With the assistance of noble metal Au, BiVO4/CoOx/Au achieved a DHA selectivity of 60 % under 1.2 V vs. RHE in pH = 2 [5]. Therefore, it’s extremely desirable and challenging to design advanced cocatalyst for BiVO4 to realize highly selective DHA production via a mild PEC strategy. In this study, we constructed a ternary photoanode comprising double cocatalyst layers, MnOx and FeOOH, on BiVO4 (denoted as BVO/Mn/Fe) and investigate the oxidation selective of glycerol to DHA as well as the photostability. MnOx is chosen because it can sustain a long stability in acid oxygen evolution reaction due to the stronger Mn-O bond [22]. We conducted comprehensive spectroscopic and computational analyses to uncover how MnOx and FeOOH together enhance DHA selectivity and accelerate the kinetics of secondary hydroxyl group oxidation in glycerol. We verified that MnOx intensified the adsorption of glycerol middle hydroxyl group and optimized the reaction pathway and energy barrier, while FeOOH effectively regulated the surface states of BiVO4 to produce more •OH radicals. The synergistic effect of MnOx and FeOOH improved the middle hydroxyl oxidation of glycerol and conversion efficiency to DHA, achieving a DHA yield of 193.3 mmol m-2h−1 and a selectivity of 52 % at 1.2 VRHE in pH = 7.0, meanwhile, maintaining a good photostability. Our study proposes a complement strategy to enhance the selectivity while suppress the photocorrosion of BiVO4-based photoanode. 2 Results and discussions 2.1 Synthesis and structural characterization of photoanodes Scheme 2 presents a synthetic process for BiVO4/MnOx/FeOOH photoanodes. The pristine BiVO4 (denoted as BVO) was prepared by electrodeposition-calcination method. Then MnOx and FeOOH were coated on BVO by electrodeposition and impregnation, respectively. We first optimized some parameters such as glycerol concentrations, Mn deposition time and Fe impregnation time, the optimal conditions are 1 M glycerol concentrations, 10 min Mn deposition time, and 8 h Fe impregnation time (Fig. S1). Fig. S2a, d showed the coral-like structure of the pristine BVO with an average diameter of about 200–300 nm and a thickness of 900 nm. Some MnOx nanoparticles with a diameter of about 80 nm can be found on the BiVO4/MnOx (BVO/Mn) (Fig. S2b). For BVO/Mn/Fe, a lot of flocculent FeOOH (20 ∼ 50 nm) wrapped around the surface of BVO and MnOx (Fig. 1 a, b and Fig. S3). It is noteworthy that more FeOOH was coated on the BVO/Mn/Fe compared to the BVO/Fe under the same impregnation time (Fig. S3c-d). This indicates that Mn ions on BVO contributes to the impregnation growth of FeOOH. The energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) maps demonstrate a uniform distribution of elements, including Bi, V, Mn, and Fe (Fig. 1c). The lattice characteristics of BVO/Mn/Fe were analyzed using high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) (Fig. 1d). The right part of the yellow dashed line corresponds to the BVO, where the lattice distance of 0.308 nm is in accordance with the {121} crystal plane. The left portion of the red dashed line represents FeOOH, where the lattice distance of 0.526 nm can be attributed to the {200} crystal plane. The central region is attributed to MnOx, and due to the poor crystallinity, no relevant lattice striations are observed. Furthermore, a selected area electron diffraction (SEAD) measurement was conducted on different photoanodes. As illustrated in Fig. S4a, the diffraction patterns exhibited multiple diffraction rings, indicating that BVO is polycrystalline. Fig. S4b presents the HR-TEM image of BVO/Mn, a fast Fourier transform of the MnOx portion demonstrated its amorphous structure. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the photoanodes is shown in Fig. 1e, where all the diffraction peaks coincide with the monoclinic crystalline phase BVO (JCPDS 14-0688) [23,24]. In addition, no diffraction peaks corresponding to MnOx and FeOOH were observed in the photoanode after modification with MnOx and FeOOH respectively, which proved the low crystallinity of MnOx and FeOOH on BVO once again. Fig. 2 a is the Raman spectra of different photoanodes at room temperature. Raman peaks located around 210, 326, 367, 711, and 826 cm−1, which are typical vibrational bands of BVO, are observed in all samples [25]. It should be noted that 210 cm−1 is the external mode of BiVO4 with little structural information. The Raman peaks observed at 326 and 367 cm−1 are attributed to the asymmetry and symmetric bending of the VO4 3- structure [26]. The peaks at 711 and 826 cm−1 originate from the antisymmetric and symmetric stretching of the V-O bonds [27]. The symmetric stretching peaks of the V-O bonds in BVO, BVO/Mn and BVO/Mn/Fe are located at 826.1, 822.7, and 822.6 cm−1, respectively. The peak of BVO/Mn shifts by 3.5 cm−1 toward lower wave numbers compared to the pristine BVO. From Eq. S1, the V-O bond lengths of BVO and BVO/Mn are 1.6457 Å and 1.6478 Å, respectively. Loading MnOx increases the V-O bond length of BVO, which implies a change in the coordination environment of the V element. This change has some effect on the photoelectrochemical reaction intermediates of BVO [28], which will be discussed in detail in later sections. The surface chemical bonding and valence states of the sample was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [29]. Fig. S5a shows the total XPS spectra of different photoanodes, the binding energy peaks of Bi, V, and Mn decrease significantly after FeOOH loading. In the fine spectrum of Bi (Fig. S5b), two binding energy peaks are observed at 159.1 and 164.4 eV, which are attributed to Bi 4f7/2 and Bi 4f5/2, respectively [30]. These two peaks had no shift after loading Mn and Fe. In Fig. 2b, the peak of V 2p shifts 0.2 eV toward higher binding energy after MnOx loaded. Specifically, the V 2p3/2 binding energies of BVO, BVO/Mn and BVO/Mn/Fe are 516.6, 516.8 and 516.8 eV, respectively [31]. An increase in the binding energy of V indicates that loading MnOx results in the electron transfer from V to Mn. The Mn 2p3/2 peak (Fig. 2c) can be divided into two parts, Mn3+ (green region) and Mn4+ (purple region), located near 641.1 and 642.3 eV respectively [32]. A negative shift of the binding energy can be clearly observed after the addition of FeOOH, indicating Fe also transfers electrons to Mn. The Fe binding energy of BVO/Mn/Fe are shown in Fig. S5c. It can be divided into three parts by split-peak fitting. 710.5 and 723.6 eV are attributed to Fe2+ (purple area), 712.0 and 725.7 eV originate from Fe3+ (blue area) and 719.8 and 733.8 eV are satellite peaks (orange area) [33]. Fig. 2d shows the O 1 s peaks at 529.7 and 531.3 eV, attributed to lattice O and chemisorbed O (e.g. –OH), respectively [34]. The peaks of chemisorbed O increased remarkably with the addition of FeOOH. The valence bands of BVO, BVO/Mn, and BVO/Mn/Fe were obtained as 1.58, 1.44, and 1.40 eV, respectively (Fig. S5d). The valence negative shift indicates the band structure change, as shown in Fig. S6, the intensity of UV absorption increased for BVO/Mn/Fe, more photo generated holes can be generated and participate in catalytic reactions. 2.2 Photo-electrochemical GOR performance Fig. 3 a presents the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve for glycerol oxidation reaction (GOR). BVO/Mn/Fe displayed the highest photocurrent density of 3.60 mA cm−2 at 1.2 VRHE in pH = 7.0, which is 1.75 times that of the pristine BVO (2.06 mA cm−2). Meanwhile, the photocurrent of BVO/Mn is 3.25 mA cm−2. It is worth noting that at a lower bias of 0.4 VRHE, the photocurrent of BVO/Mn/Fe is 0.87 mA cm−2, much higher than pristine BVO (0.13 mA cm−2). This means that modifying MnOx and FeOOH remarkably enhanced the glycerol oxidation efficiency at lower potentials. In addition, BVO/Fe showed a photocurrent of 2.27 mA cm−2 at 1.2 VRHE (Fig. S7), this suggests that only the synergy of Mn and Fe can achieve a superior GOR performance. Furthermore, the photoanode demonstrated a photocurrent density of 1.60 mA cm−2 at 1.2 VRHE for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) (Fig. S8), indicating OER can be replaced by GOR for more efficient hydrogen production. The incident photon conversion efficiency (IPCE) spectra of different photoanodes for GOR at 1.2 VRHE were collected in Fig. S9. BVO/Mn/Fe exhibits an excellent IPCE of 83 % in the range of 400 ∼ 450 nm due to the enhanced UV absorption, much higher than 75 % for BVO/Mn and 50 % for pristine BVO. After 12 h of stability testing, the photocurrent of the pristine BVO decayed to the initial 55.4 % (Fig. 3b). The stability of BVO/Mn and BVO/Mn/Fe maintained 91.9 % and 97.2 % of the initial photocurrent under 12 h irradiation in pH = 7.0, exhibiting the strong protective effect of the binary co-catalysts. In addition, after 12 h of stability testing, the pristine BVO surface became smooth due to severe photo corrosion [35], at the same time, BVO/Mn/Fe almost kept the coral structure (Fig. S10). The selectivity of glycerol oxidation products were analyzed by nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) [36,37]. The typical NMR 1H spectrum is shown in Fig. S11a, and the products are mainly composed of formic acid (FA), dihydroxyacetone (DHA) and glyceric acid (GLA). At the same time, 20 mg/L dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was added to the liquid product as an internal standard to conduct the quantitative analysis of the products. The standard curve obtained by the internal standard is shown in Fig. S11b–d. The glycerol oxidation yield at 1.2 VRHE is displayed in Fig. 3c. The yield of DHA on BVO/Mn/Fe is 193.3 mmol m-2h−1, 2.8 times higher than that of the pristine BVO (68.5 mmol m-2h−1). It is worth noting that at a lower potential of 0.4 VRHE, the production of DHA on BVO/Mn/Fe is 60.1 mmol m-2h−1, which is 55 times higher than the original BVO (1.1 mmol m-2h−1) (Fig. 3d). The product selectivity at 1.2 VRHE is shown in Fig. 3e. The selectivity of DHA for BVO/Mn/Fe is 52 %, significantly higher than the pristine BVO (35 %) and BVO/Mn (42 %). The Faraday efficiency (FE) of DHA production for BVO, BVO/Mn, and BVO/Mn/Fe were 27.3 %, 33.2 %, and 41.6 %, respectively (Fig. 3g). At a potential of 0.4 VRHE, the selectivity of BVO/Mn/Fe can still reach 44 %, which is 2.75 times that of pristine BVO (16 %) (Fig. 3f). For comparison, the photoanode yield and selectivity of BVO/Fe were also measured and the results are shown in Fig. S12. The DHA yields and selectivity of BVO/Fe at 1.2 VRHE and 0.4 VRHE were also significantly lower than that of BVO/Mn/Fe. This indicates that the synergistic effect of MnOx and FeOOH improves the selectivity and yield of DHA. In the selectivity results of glycerol oxidation at 1.6 VRHE, it can be observed that formic acid becomes the main product of glycerol oxidation. This indicates that higher potentials may lead to over-oxidation, causing the cleavage of C–C bonds and generating more C1 products (Fig. S13). Therefore, we primarily use 1.2 VRHE as the oxidation potential to discuss the selective oxidation of glycerol to DHA. The long-term stable yield test of BVO/Mn/Fe was carried out using the series device of Fig. S15, and the hydrogen produced at the cathode was collected by the drainage gas collection method. The absence of bubbles at the anode indicates that the products are all dissolved in the aqueous solution and the yield of hydrogen is 328.25 mmol m-2h−1. During the long reaction time (6 h, 8 h), the yield of DHA decreased slightly. This may be due to the fact that the DHA product in the solution will continue to be oxidized by the photoanode, which is difficult to avoid in a non-flow device. In addition, the other works related to the selective oxidation of glycerol to DHA are summarized in Table S2. 2.3 Oxidation mechanism and surface states of photoanodes It has been reported that the photoelectrochemical oxidation of glycerol on pristine BVO usually caused by hydroxyl radical ⋅OH [7,15]. To discuss the oxidation mechanism of BVO/Mn/Fe, DMPO was used as a scavenger and room temperature electron spin resonance (ESR) measurements were performed [38]. As shown in Fig. 4 a, BVO/Mn/Fe exhibits an ESR signal of 1:2:2:1 under illumination in Na2SO4 aqueous solution, indicating the characteristic signal of ·OH [39]. After adding glycerol to the solution, another set of characteristic signals related to carbon center free radicals was observed. Next, free radical quenching experiments were performed [9]. As shown in Fig. 4b, after the addition of TEMPO (radical scavengers) and Na2SO3 (photogenerated hole scavenger), the consumption of glycerol was very low, indexing free radicals and photogenerated holes play an important role in the oxidation of glycerol. In contrast, when K2S2O8 (photoelectron scavenger) was added, the consumption of glycerol was almost the same as no scavenger was added. This shows that photogenerated electrons have almost no effect on the oxidation of glycerol. The results of free radical quenching experiments and ESR demonstrates that BVO/Mn/Fe has the same GOR oxidation mechanism of pristine BVO, photogenerated holes oxidize water into hydroxyl radicals and then oxidize glycerol to DHA [40]. Coumarin can be used as a fluorescent probe to effectively detect hydroxyl radicals in the solution [7]. 0.2 mM coumarin was added to the electrolyte containing the catalyst as a fluorescent probe. Fluorescence spectroscopy was performed after 10 min of AM 1.5G illumination under a bias of 1.2 VRHE. The fluorescence intensity at 460 nm reflects the ·OH content in the solution. As shown in Fig. 4c, the fluorescence intensity of BVO/Mn/Fe is much higher than that of BVO and BVO/Mn. At the same time, a strong fluorescence signal was observed with H2O2 as the control group. This shows that BVO/Mn/Fe can indeed produce more ·OH under illumination for glycerol oxidation [41]. The quantity of hydroxyl radicals is related to the surface states of BVO photoanode. Then we employed cyclic voltammetry (CV) technique to analyze the surface states [42,43]. The photoanodes were first illuminated at a potential of 2.6 VRHE for 120 s, and then quickly performed cyclic voltammetry scanning in the dark. The first scan cycle reflects the recombination of photogenerated electrons and holes in the conduction band. As shown in Fig. 5 a, two redox reactions were observed in the first scanning cycle, one was the surface state of the reaction intermediate attributed to the redox process of V4+/V5+ (Eq. (1) at 1.0 VRHE (peak 1), and the other was the surface state of the composite site caused by the irreversible surface reaction of VO2 +/VO2+ (Eq. (2) at 1.5 VRHE (peak 2). The two redox processes can be represented by the following equations [44,45]: (1) V 5 + s u r f a c e + e - i n j e c t e d ⇄ V 4 + s u r f a c e (2) VO 2 + s u r f a c e + 2 H + a q + e photo - ⟶ VO 2 + s u r f a c e + H 2 Eq. (1) represents the active surface states (a-ss) and Eq. (2) stands for the recombination surface states (r-ss). According to Fig. 5a-c, compared with the pristine BVO, BVO/Mn can effectively suppress r-ss. After further modification with FeOOH, a-ss significantly increased. This shows that addition of MnOx effectively suppresses the recombination of photogenerated carriers at BVO surface, and FeOOH significantly increases the active sites, thereby efficiently generating more photo-induced holes and hydroxyl radicals. Photoelectrochemical impedance spectroscopy (PEIS) measurements were conducted to further evaluate the surface states and charge transfer processes (Fig. S16) [44,46]. The appropriate equivalent circuit diagram (Fig. S17) was used for analysis. The fitting results of the PEIS spectrum are shown in Fig. S18. Capacitance surface state (CSS) usually represents the amount of surface reaction intermediates during aqueous solution oxidation. As shown in Fig. S18a, BVO and BVO/Mn have similar CSS trends, they both have an obvious capacitance peak at 1.1 VRHE. Interestingly, CSS for BVO/Mn/Fe is much higher at 1.1 VRHE. This suggests that the BVO/Mn/Fe generates more reaction intermediates as reaction sites during glycerol oxidation. In addition, it shows a significant increase at 0.4 VRHE, this means that even at lower potentials, BVO/Mn/Fe can still produce active intermediates to oxidize glycerol, consisting with the product selectivity at 0.4 VRHE in GOR performance aforementioned. Fig. S18b described the data of bulk charge accumulation (CBulk), and it can be found that BVO＞BVO/Mn＞BVO/Mn/Fe. This illustrates that more charges in BVO/Mn/Fe can migrate to the surface to participate in the GOR. In addition, a capacitance peak was observed at around 1.0 VRHE, which was caused by the charge accumulation during the V4+/V5+ redox process in the bulk [45]. The resistance of surface charge transfer (RSS) was presented in Fig. S18c. The resistance of all samples gradually decreased with the increase of applied potential. BVO/Mn/Fe has a significantly lower RSS than pristine BVO and BVO/Mn, indicating FeOOH facilitates the charge oxidation of glycerol at the semiconductor solution interface (SEI). The bulk charge transfer resistance (RBulk) of the photoanodes is shown in Fig. S18d. BVO/Mn owns a lower RBulk than pristine BVO at high potentials. This means the electron transfer at the interface of BVO and MnOx were promoted under high bias, thereby reducing the bulk charge recombination. The RBulk value of BVO/Mn/Fe further decreased, ascribing to the covalent bonds (Fe-O-V) formed between the surface oxygen sites and Fe atoms. The ratio of NSS/Nd is a good parameter to define the balance between the active surface state (a-ss) density and the charge donor density [44,47]. Where NSS is the surface state density obtained by dividing CSS by the elementary charge e in PEIS measurement, and Nd is the carrier density obtained in M−S measurement (Fig. S19). The results are shown in Fig. 5d, where the NSS/Nd of BVO, BVO/Mn and BVO/Mn/Fe are 16.57, 19.49 and 26.98 μm, respectively. BVO/Mn/Fe demonstrates high Nd and better NSS/Nd, corresponding to its fast charge transfer kinetic and sufficient surface reaction sites. Combining the free radical measurements and surface state measurements, it is reasonable to deduce that MnOx effectively promotes the electrons transfer and suppresses the recombination of photogenerated holes, FeOOH produce more active intermediate species under illumination and bias, thereby more hydroxyl radicals are produced to efficiently oxidize glycerol. 2.4 Catalytic mechanisms and reaction pathways To further explore the underlying mechanisms responsible for the enhanced GOR performance and selectivity, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was employed to track the intermediates generated during GOR. As model molecules, n-propanol and isopropanol are widely used to distinguish the adsorption tendency of primary and secondary hydroxyl groups during glycerol oxidation. Fig. 6 a shows the infrared adsorption spectrum of n-propanol, in which multiple infrared vibration peaks were observed, including the methyl symmetric and asymmetric stretching vibrations ν(CH3) at 2961 and 2876 cm−1, the methyl symmetric and asymmetric bending vibrations δ(CH3) at 1345 and 1235 cm−1, and the C-O stretching vibration (ν(C-O)) at 1153 cm−1 [2,40]. The ν(C-O) band shifts from 1053 (BVO) to 1057 and 1056 cm−1 (BVO/Mn and BVO/Mn/Fe), respectively. The shifts towards higher wavenumbers means a weaker bond energy [2,15]. This illustrates that the primary hydroxyl adsorption of n-propanol on BVO/Mn is weaker than on BVO. In addition, when adsorbing isopropanol, the ν (C-O) bands on BVO, BVO/Mn and BVO/Mn/Fe are 1160, 1156 and 1156 cm−1, respectively (Fig. 6b). This demonstrates BVO/Mn has a stronger adsorption of secondary hydroxyl groups on isopropanol than BVO. In addition, the adsorption of n-propanol and isopropanol by BVO/Mn/Fe is not much different from that of BVO/Mn, indicating that MnOx mainly affects the adsorption of secondary hydroxyl groups. To further investigate the origin of the high selectivity toward DHA, we utilized FTIR spectroscopy to assess the desorption of acetone molecules from different photoanode surfaces (Fig. S20). Acetone molecules exhibit two characteristic absorption bands at 1698 cm−1 and 1215 cm−1, corresponding to the ν(C=O) and ν(C–C) vibrations, respectively [9]. On the BVO/Mn surface, the ν(C=O) band remains at 1698 cm−1, showing almost no difference compared to pristine BVO, which suggests that acetone is not readily desorbed from BVO/Mn. In contrast, on the BVO/Mn/Fe photoanode, the ν(C=O) band shifts to a higher wavenumber at 1704 cm−1, accompanied by a reduction in peak intensity. This confirms that acetone is less likely to adsorb on the surface of this photoanode. Combined adsorption–desorption analysis reveals that the high DHA selectivity of BVO/Mn/Fe is attributed not only to its strong adsorption capability toward secondary hydroxyl groups but also to its ability to rapidly desorb oxidized ketone intermediates. For the purpose of exploring the oxidation process of glycerol photoelectrochemical oxidation, in situ attenuated total reflection Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy was tested on BVO/Mn/Fe in 0.2 M Na2SO4 solution containing 1 M glycerol. As shown in Fig. 6c, the peak at 1740 cm−1 is assigned to the generation of carbonyl-containing substances, such as aldehydes, ketones, etc., which indicates the initial oxidation of glycerol. An obvious carbonyl peak was observed at around 0.5 VRHE, further illustrates that BVO/Mn/Fe can oxidize glycerol to dihydroxyacetone at a lower potential. The continuous peak at 1630 cm−1 is related to the –OH bending vibration in the electrolyte. The peak between 1400 and 1583 cm−1 represents the carboxyl group, and its intensity gradually increases with the increase of potential, indicating the transformation of glycerol to organic acid [36,48]. Density functional theory (DFT) was calculated to clarify the active sites and oxidation reaction pathway of glycerol on BVO and BVO/Mn [7]. The adsorption energy of glycerol secondary hydroxyl groups is −5.76 eV for Mn site, much higher than −0.67 eV of Bi site (Fig. S22), showing that BVO/Mn has a better affinity for glycerol secondary hydroxyl groups than BVO. Due to steric hindrance, glycerol is more easily oxidized to DHA after the intermediate hydroxyl groups are adsorbed [7,49]. Therefore, on BVO/Mn/Fe, glycerol molecules are mainly adsorbed on Mn atoms through intermediate hydroxyl groups, the addition of FeOOH on the surface promote the generation of reaction intermediates and more hydroxyl radicals. The reaction path and energy barrier of glycerol oxidation to DHA after adsorption on the photoanode surface were further calculated. As shown in Fig. 6d, the first step of the reaction is the adsorption of secondary hydroxyl groups of glycerol on active sites. The adsorbed glycerol is then oxidized and dehydrogenated by hydroxyl radicals in the solution to form carbon-centered free radicals. Subsequently, the carbon-centered free radicals combine with hydroxyl radicals to form reaction intermediates. Finally, the intermediates are dehydrated to form DHA [11]. It is worth noting that on the pristine BVO surface, the rate-determining step is the dehydration process in the fourth step with an energy barrier of 0.89 eV. On the BVO/Mn photoanode, the rate-determining step is the oxidation in the second step to form carbon-centered free radicals, and its energy barrier is 0.87 eV. Based on the above results, both MnOx and FeOOH are essential for the selective oxidation of glycerol to DHA. Their synergistic effect leads to a significant increase in selectivity and yield. The schematic diagram of the photoelectrochemical glycerol oxidation by BVO/Mn/Fe photoanode is shown in Fig. 6e. BVO can generate photogenerated electron-hole pairs, and holes migrate to the surface of the photoanode to participate in the oxidation reaction. MnOx on the surface of the photoanode has a higher adsorption energy for the secondary hydroxyl groups of glycerol, and can efficiently adsorb glycerol and regulate the rate-determining step. FeOOH on the surface regulates the surface states of the photoanode, form more intermediate active surface states and hydroxyl radicals, and efficiently oxidize glycerol adsorbed on MnOx to DHA. This synergistic effect intensifies the middle hydroxyl oxidation and the product selectivity of glycerol as well as the stability of BVO. 3 Conclusions In summary, a nanoporous BiVO4 photoanode modified with binary co-catalysts MnOx and FeOOH was successfully constructed by electrochemical deposition and solution impregnation, which exhibited excellent performance toward the selective oxidation of glycerol into high-value-added DHA in neutral condition. The influences of MnOx and FeOOH on GOR oxidation mechanism, as well as their role in regulating the surface states and interfacial transfer kinetics have been meticulously explored through a combination of experimental characterization and theoretical calculation. Analyses such as electrochemical and spectroscopic measurements elucidate that MnOx can effectively suppress the recombination surface states on BVO and selectively adsorb the secondary hydroxyl groups of glycerol, this finding is further supported by the DFT calculations. The Gibbs free energy evolution calculations also confirm a changed rate-determining step and decreased energy barrier on MnOx. FeOOH significantly increase the active surface states on BVO, generating more photo-induced holes and hydroxyl radicals. Finally, the optimized BVO/Mn/Fe photoanode exhibits a DHA evolution rate of 193.3 mmol m-2h−1 and a selectivity about 52 % under an applied bias of 1.2 VRHE in pH = 7.0 with good stability. Even at a low potential of 0.4 VRHE, BVO/Mn/Fe can maintain a selectivity of 44 % for DHA. This work provides an efficient strategy to synthesize high-value products from glycerol through accelerating middle hydroxyl oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Enhancing the selective oxidation of glycerol into 1,3-dihydroxyacetone (DHA) on a photoanode is attractive but challenging due to the complex reaction pathway. At present, the 20 % selectivity of DHA products on a BiVO4 photoanode in neutral condition as well as its photocorrosion prove to be below expectations. In this work, we decorated binary co-catalysts MnOx/FeOOH on BiVO4 (denoted BVO/Mn/Fe) for the selective photoelectrocatalytic glycerol to DHA. The BVO/Mn/Fe photoanode exhibited a DHA selectivity of 52 % at 1.2 VRHE with an evolution rate of 193.3 mmol m-2h−1 in pH = 7.0, and maintained 97.2 % of the initial photocurrent after 12 h stability test. The role of MnOx and FeOOH in the selective oxidation of glycerol was investigated through comprehensive spectroscopic and computational methods. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy showed that the middle hydroxyl group preferentially adsorbs onto MnOx surfaces, density function theory calculations verified the optimized rate-determining step and decreased energy barrier by MnOx. Meanwhile, FeOOH significantly increased the active surface states on BiVO4 and produced more hydroxyl radicals. The synergistic effect of MnOx and FeOOH promoted the middle hydroxyl oxidation of glycerol and conversion efficiency to DHA on BiVO4 under neutral condition.
